author: Australian Associated Press
title: Christchurch fire forces 1,000 people to flee their homes
text:
New Zealand Christchurch fire forces 1,000 people to flee their homes 
Blaze destroys at least seven houses, sparking local state of emergency in New Zealand’s second largest city Wednesday 15 February 2017 23.52 GMT Last modified on Thursday 16 February 2017 00.17 GMT 
More than 1,000 people have fled their homes and at least seven houses have been destroyed by the major bushfire in the New Zealand city of Christchurch . 
Around 450 homes were officially evacuated on Thursday morning. Video footage showed flames just metres from some properties. 'Long way to go': Christchurch fights to emerge from shadow of 2011 earthquake Read more 
“We understand it’s hard for people to leave their homes but the fire can change direction and move incredibly quickly,” said senior sergeant Ash Tabb. Grant (@viralpoet) February 13, 2017 
The blaze, which started as two separate fires on Monday, and which sparked a local civil defence state of emergency, was fanned by a wind change and merged into one blaze which covered more than 1850 hectares (4,570 acres) by Wednesday night, authorities said. 
It has already claimed the life of helicopter pilot Steve Askin, who crashed while fighting the fire on Tuesday. Sixteen firefighting helicopters took to the air at first light on Thursday but rain isn’t expected until Friday afternoon. 
“It’s not a really good forecast for firefighting ... we are expecting winds to develop this afternoon,” civil defence controller Dave Adamson told Radio New Zealand . 
On Thursday morning, Christchurch civil defence said a temperature drop and rise in humidity had improved conditions. An easterly wind was expected to turn into a northerly during the morning, with wind speeds picking up to 30km/h in the afternoon. Chris van der Leer (@cvanderleer) February 15, 2017 
“At this point in time the fire’s not threatening any other properties ... but we’ll just have to see how the day and the fire develops,” Adamson said. 
Around 120 firefighters and support crew have been involved in ground operations since the fire broke out on Monday night. About 85 New Zealand defence force personnel are also helping with efforts to fight the blaze.
